moves.1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. d4 Bb4: Blunder simply giving away the N on c5. Correct was Ne6
moves.13. Bxc5 Bxf3 14. gxf3 Nxc5 15. Rxc5: Leaving black with an isolated central pawn and no developed pieces
moves.15... Qe7 16. Rxd5 Rad8 17. Bg2 Rxd5: When you are behind in material and development it is not a good idea to swap of pieces
moves.18. Qxd5 Rd8 19. Qe4 Qd7: back rank mate threat which is easily avoided by 0-0
moves.20. O-O Re8 21. Bh3 Qd8 22. Qxb7 Re7: This constant harrying of the Q achieves only a further exchange of pieces
moves.27... Re5 28. Bd7 Rg5+ 29. Kh1 Rd5 30. R: Setting up the shield which will allow the b-pawn to Q
moves.31... Rd6: Probaly the worst place to put the R. Now it cannot even get to a position to sac itself for the new Q
moves.32. b5 h5: Aseeming pointless move but one which could catch the unaware out
moves.33. b6 h4 34. b7 h3: Now if white gets tunnel vision on the Q promotion it would be possible to miss the back rank mate Rd1
moves.35. Rh8+: The R is safe as if KxR then b8=Q+ and the R is lost
moves.35... Kg6 36. Be4+: At this poi nt black asked if i was toying with him. But no i still had to stop Rd1
moves.36... f5 37. Bc2 Rd2 38. b8=Q Rxc2 39. Q: The lesson from this game is keep an eye on the whole board or you may miss something important.
